summary: Whole .NET Framework for auto-completion and use in scripts  (C#  Vb .Net)
name: Dotnet-Dictionaries
description:
In the dictionary-files you find the whole .NET-Framework (v1.0.3705) for auto-completion or use in scripts. There are all namespaces, all classes and all functions - at least I hope so.

The entries are organized according to the main dlls. 
E.g. mscorlib.dll becomes mscorlib.dict.

The dictionaries:
SystemData.dict
MicrosoftVisualBasic.dict
MicrosoftVsa.dict
mscorlib.dict
system.dict
SystemConfigurationInstall.dict
cscompmgd.dict
SystemDesign.dict
SystemDirectoryServices.dict
SystemDrawing.dict
SystemDrawingDesign.dict
SystemEnterpriseServices.dict
SystemManagement.dict
SystemMessaging.dict
SystemRuntimeRemoting.dict
SystemSecurity.dict
SystemWebServices.dict
SystemWindowsForms.dict
SystemXml.dict

Example from mscorlib.dict:
System.String.Length
System.String.op_Equality(System.String,System.String)
System.String.op_Inequalit(System.String,System.String)
System.String.PadLeft(System.Int32)
System.String.PadLeft(System.Int32,System.Char)
System.String.PadRight(System.Int32)
System.String.PadRight(System.Int32,System.Char)
System.String.Remove(System.Int32,System.Int32)
System.String.Replace(System.Char,System.Char)
System.String.Replace(System.String,System.String)
System.String.Split(System.Char[])
...

I hope someone invents a good possibilty to use theses entries. 
Please let me know what you have done.

Regards,

--Klaus Horsten
install_details:
Look into the vim-reference:
type :h ins-completion

Note that for whole line completion you should turn hidden on; 
type: :set hidden
and you have to switch at least once into the buffer with the dictionary-file 
(e.g. with :bn  and :bp).
